head.title: Taxes as a Part of Life, and Death

hedline.hl1: Taxes as a Part of Life, and Death

abstract.p: Surinder Singh letter replies to Charles W Kadlec's Aug 1 Op-Ed article on taxes, rejecting argument that estate tax discourages savings and investment and encourages squandering of assets; cartoon

block.p: Charles W. Kadlec argues that the estate tax is flawed and should be repealed (Op-Ed, Aug. 1). But if it really discourages savings and investment and encourages the squandering of assets, why do we have a higher percentage of millionaires and billionaires, adjusted for inflation, than at any time in history?

Charles W. Kadlec argues that the estate tax is flawed and should be repealed (Op-Ed, Aug. 1). But if it really discourages savings and investment and encourages the squandering of assets, why do we have a higher percentage of millionaires and billionaires, adjusted for inflation, than at any time in history?

If anything, the tax encourages the wealthy to be altruistic. A wealthy individual is more likely to make generous gifts to a charity that provides scholarships for disadvantaged students when the donation will reduce his or her estate-tax burden.
